WETA, Washington, has expanded its TV Job Center program to four nights
each week. Also, its series of evening-long Town Meetings on the educational,
social, economic and political problems and issues confronting the District of
Columbia public schools, and the station's role in the EEN "Help Wanted" program.
131 Florida, the Director of Radio and ETV for the Department of Education
called a meeting in the state capital of community leaders, station managers
from across the state, and members of the State Advisory Board on ETV and
Radio, to explore the efforts and prospects for improving the status of deprived
citizens and enhancing race relations. The State Department of Education will
provide video tape for programs -- and subsidies for TV and radio production
costs -- which concentrate on the problems and solutions that are being attempted,
rather than paying excessive attention to violence.
In New Orleans, WYES broadcast "An End To Talk", a panel on race
relations. It provided participation by a large studio audience, and home viewing
audience (by telephone). Moderated by a Louisiana jurist, the discussion turned
out to be lively and candid. The panel included a law professor, a Negro dentist,
and "an angry unemployed black man, a powerful white shipbuilder, and a top
Labor Department official, " according to the local newspaper.
In Boston, the night that Martin Luther King, Jr. was assassinated, soul
rock singer James Brown and "The Flames" were booked at the Boston Garden,
and 15, 000 black youngsters were expected to show up (as reported by WGBH's
Hartford Gunn at the April 21, ETS Day meeting). Mayor Kevin White (who is_
white), and Councilman Tom Atkins (who is Negro) were concerned that either a
cancellation of the event or_a performance as scheduled might compound problems.
At the Mayor's request, WGBH (the only station that could send an all-black crew
to cover the event) broadcast the performance live, repeated it later the same
night, and the following night. White, Atkins and Brown appealed to the viewers
to stay home, and the program is credited with helping to control a potentially
disastrous situation.
Beginning later this month, WGBH will broadcast its own weekly "black
magazine" (repeated once each week). "Say, Brother" will include news of the
ghetto, features on black people and activities, a forum for Negro opinion, and
a showcase for black artists, performers and entertainers. The production
